classification.name: caArray_1.1

classification.name: C3PR
classification.preferredDefinition: Version 2.8 The Cancer Central Clinical Participent Registry (C3PR) is a web-based application used to manage participants in cancer clinical trials. Research staff will use C3PR as a participant-centric entry point to clinical trial management systems. C3PR provides a central registry for study participants, and it enables the end-user to access participant-centric information that is stored in multiple clinical trial systems. Participants that can be tracked include patients or potential patients, their guardians, family members, and referring physicians. The system also allows tracking other types of participants such as principal investigators, caregivers, referring physicians, and the users of the system.

C3PR provides a central registry for study participants, and it enables the end-user to access participant-centric information that is stored in multiple clinical trial systems. Participants that can be tracked include patients or potential patients, their guardians, family members, and referring physicians. The system also allows tracking other types of participants such as principal investigators, caregivers, referring physicians, and the users of the system.

dataElement.longName: Laboratory Procedure CA-125 Antigen Tumor Marker Result Value
dataElement.preferredDefinition: a numeric result for the result of the medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood or tissue for CA-125 tumor marker, an antigen expressed by tissues derived from mullerian epithelium (tubal, endometrial and endocervical) or celomic epithelium (mesothelial cells of the pleura, pericardium and peritoneum) and may mean that ovarian cancer present.

dataElement.longName: Laboratory Procedure CA-125 Antigen Tumor Marker Result Date
dataElement.preferredDefinition: the date of the medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood or tissue for CA-125 tumor marker, an antigen expressed by tissues derived from mullerian epithelium (tubal, endometrial and endocervical) or celomic epithelium (mesothelial cells of the pleura, pericardium and peritoneum) and may mean that ovarian cancer present.

dataElement.longName: Gynecologic Malignant Neoplasm Progression Anatomic Site
dataElement.preferredDefinition: a structure or organ within the body to which cancer (atypical neoplastic cells) originating in the female reproductive organs has spread indicating advancement of disease.

valueDomain.longName: Gynecologic Malignant Neoplasm Progression Anatomic Site

valueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.
Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.
PARAMETRIAL INVOLVEMENT

classification.name: Common Biorepository Model
classification.preferredDefinition: A common model to contain summary-level details of biorepository / biobank holdings which can be advertised through the OBBR Specimen Resource Locator

valueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (PAIR-ih-toe-NEE-um) The tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen.

(PLOOR-a) A thin layer of tissue covering the lungs and the wall of the chest cavity to protect and cushion the lungs. A small amount of fluid that acts as a lubricant allows the lungs to move smoothly in the chest cavity during breathing.
Pleural effusion

One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova; surrounding this stroma is a more condensed layer of stroma called the tunica albuginea.
Ascites

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.
A large organ located in the upper abdomen. The liver cleanses the blood and aids in digestion by secreting bile.
An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.
(SER-viks) The lower, narrow end of the uterus that forms a canal between the uterus and vagina.

The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.
Endometrium
A hollow, thick-walled, muscular organ located within the pelvic cavity of a woman. Within the uterus the fertilized egg implants and the fetus develops during pregnancy.
The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

dataElement.preferredDefinition: a text field to describe a position within the body of a rounded mass of lymphatic tissue.
the free text field to identify the anatomic location of additional sites of metastatic or progressive disease.

classification.name: PICUcoreClinicalData
classification.preferredDefinition: Descriptive information about pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) discharges from NICHD Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network (CPCCRN) Clinical Centers, based primarily on hospital billing databases. The Core Clinical Data Project (CCDP) provides pilot and descriptive data for hypothesis generation, study design, preliminary power analyses, and recruitment projections for CPCCRN studies under development.

classification.name: C3PR
classification.preferredDefinition: Version 2.8 The Cancer Central Clinical Participent Registry (C3PR) is a web-based application used to manage participants in cancer clinical trials. Research staff will use C3PR as a participant-centric entry point to clinical trial management systems. C3PR provides a central registry for study participants, and it enables the end-user to access participant-centric information that is stored in multiple clinical trial systems. Participants that can be tracked include patients or potential patients, their guardians, family members, and referring physicians. The system also allows tracking other types of participants such as principal investigators, caregivers, referring physicians, and the users of the system.

The Core Clinical Data Project (CCDP) provides pilot and descriptive data for hypothesis generation, study design, preliminary power analyses, and recruitment projections for CPCCRN studies under development.

classification.name: PICUcoreClinicalData
classification.preferredDefinition: Descriptive information about pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) discharges from NICHD Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network (CPCCRN) Clinical Centers, based primarily on hospital billing databases. The Core Clinical Data Project (CCDP) provides pilot and descriptive data for hypothesis generation, study design, preliminary power analyses, and recruitment projections for CPCCRN studies under development.

classification.name: C3PR
classification.preferredDefinition: Version 2.8 The Cancer Central Clinical Participent Registry (C3PR) is a web-based application used to manage participants in cancer clinical trials. Research staff will use C3PR as a participant-centric entry point to clinical trial management systems. C3PR provides a central registry for study participants, and it enables the end-user to access participant-centric information that is stored in multiple clinical trial systems. Participants that can be tracked include patients or potential patients, their guardians, family members, and referring physicians. The system also allows tracking other types of participants such as principal investigators, caregivers, referring physicians, and the users of the system.

Research staff will use C3PR as a participant-centric entry point to clinical trial management systems. C3PR provides a central registry for study participants, and it enables the end-user to access participant-centric information that is stored in multiple clinical trial systems.
